elements.content: The reaction of 2,3-dimethylquinoxaline (dmq) with copper(II) halides in water/ethanol solution yields a variety of copper(I) compounds. The major products have the stoichiometry (dmq)Cu2X2. Crystal structure analysis of the bromide compound reveals the presence of Cu4Br4 tetramers with a chair conformation. These are linked into chains by pairs of dmq ligands. Upon prolonged heating of the system, a compound can be isolated in which both of the methyl groups of the dmq molecule have been monobrominated. The crystal structure of this compound, (dBrdmqH)CuBr2, contains one dimensional (CuBr2) n n - chains of edge shared tetrahedra.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of 2,3-dimethylquinoxaline (dmq) with copper(II) halides in water/ethanol solution yields a variety of copper(I) compounds. The major products have the stoichiometry (dmq)Cu2X2. Crystal structure analysis of the bromide compound reveals the presence of Cu4Br4 tetramers with a chair conformation. These are linked into chains by pairs of dmq ligands. Upon prolonged heating of the system, a compound can be isolated in which both of the methyl groups of the dmq molecule have been monobrominated. The crystal structure of this compound, (dBrdmqH)CuBr2, contains one dimensional (CuBr2) n   n  - chains of edge shared tetrahedra.

elements.content: The design of low dimensional coordination polymers involving Cu(I) and/or Cu(II) halides is one of the current crystal engineering goals in our laboratory. One particular interest is in the development of rectangular two-dimensional magnetic systems. One strategy is to build one-dimensional halide structures that are bridged by nonchelating bidentate ligands. To this end, the reaction of copper(II) halides with 2,3-dimethylquinoxaline (henceforth, dmq) was undertaken with the goal of obtaining systems analogous to the pyrazine complexes, but with larger interlayer spacing due to the additional bulk of the dmq ligand. As frequently is observed in our syntheses with copper(II) halides, chemical processes involving reduction of Cu(II) occur, and these are often accompanied by halogenation of the organic species. The three solid materials, two bromide and one chloride containing compounds, isolated in our study are all Cu(I) complexes. In addition, bromination of the methyl groups of the dmq molecule was found to occur in one of the compounds isolated. These results give further evidence for these processes. Structural analysis of the two bromide compounds is reported. The first of these compounds, (dmq)Cu2Br2, complements recent structural studies of such systems obtained by more conventional synthetic routes. The copper halide framework in the second compound, (dBrmqH)CuBr2, where dBrmqH+ is the 2,3-di(bromomethyl)quinoxalinium cation, mirrors the structural characteristics of the paraquat salts of copper(I).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design of low dimensional coordination polymers involving Cu(I) and/or Cu(II) halides is one of the current crystal engineering goals in our laboratory. One particular interest is in the development of rectangular two-dimensional magnetic systems. One strategy is to build one-dimensional halide structures that are bridged by nonchelating bidentate ligands. To this end, the reaction of copper(II) halides with 2,3-dimethylquinoxaline (henceforth, dmq) was undertaken with the goal of obtaining systems analogous to the pyrazine complexes, but with larger interlayer spacing due to the additional bulk of the dmq ligand. As frequently is observed in our syntheses with copper(II) halides, chemical processes involving reduction of Cu(II) occur, and these are often accompanied by halogenation of the organic species. The three solid materials, two bromide and one chloride containing compounds, isolated in our study are all Cu(I) complexes. In addition, bromination of the methyl groups of the dmq molecule was found to occur in one of the compounds isolated. These results give further evidence for these processes. Structural analysis of the two bromide compounds is reported. The first of these compounds, (dmq)Cu2Br2, complements recent structural studies of such systems obtained by more conventional synthetic routes. The copper halide framework in the second compound, (dBrmqH)CuBr2, where dBrmqH+ is the 2,3-di(bromomethyl)quinoxalinium cation, mirrors the structural characteristics of the paraquat salts of copper(I).

elements.content: Syntheses. (dmq)Cu 2 Br 2 (1). Anhydrous copper(II) bromide (1.03 g, 4.62 mmol) was added to 30 mL of 95% ethanol. The mixture was warmed, and the copper salt dissolved upon the addition of 5 mL of distilled water to give a green/black solution. The 2,3-dimethylquinozaline (0.722 g, 4.56 mmol) was dissolved in 30 mL of warm 95% ethanol. The warm copper solution was then added to the warm, colorless dmq solution to give a reddish brown solution. Upon evaporation of the solvent, reddish brown crystals began to form. The crystals were collected by filtration and allowed to air dry. Yield:  0.577 g, 56%. Elemental Analysis:  Calcd. C, 26.98; H, 2.26; N, 6.29; Br, 35.90; Found C, 26.96; H, 2.19; N, 6.24; Br, 35.92. IR (KBr):  3009.4 w, 1553.1 w, 1487.5 m, 1396.5 m, 1379.1 m, 1332.1 m, 1198.5 m, 1175.9 m, 1136.1 m, 1001.6 m, 957.8 m, 836.3 m, 771.9 s. A crystal with dimensions approximately 0.16 × 0.07 × 0.03 mm was selected for the diffraction study.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Syntheses. (dmq)Cu  2  Br  2   (1). Anhydrous copper(II) bromide (1.03 g, 4.62 mmol) was added to 30 mL of 95% ethanol. The mixture was warmed, and the copper salt dissolved upon the addition of 5 mL of distilled water to give a green/black solution. The 2,3-dimethylquinozaline (0.722 g, 4.56 mmol) was dissolved in 30 mL of warm 95% ethanol. The warm copper solution was then added to the warm, colorless dmq solution to give a reddish brown solution. Upon evaporation of the solvent, reddish brown crystals began to form. The crystals were collected by filtration and allowed to air dry. Yield: 0.577 g, 56%. Elemental Analysis: Calcd. C, 26.98; H, 2.26; N, 6.29; Br, 35.90; Found C, 26.96; H, 2.19; N, 6.24; Br, 35.92. IR (KBr): 3009.4 w, 1553.1 w, 1487.5 m, 1396.5 m, 1379.1 m, 1332.1 m, 1198.5 m, 1175.9 m, 1136.1 m, 1001.6 m, 957.8 m, 836.3 m, 771.9 s. A crystal with dimensions approximately 0.16 × 0.07 × 0.03 mm was selected for the diffraction study.

elements.content: (dBrmqH)CuBr 2 (2). 0.5 mmol of CuBr2 (0.112 g) and 0.5 mmol of dmq (0.079 g) were dissolved in 50 mL of 95% ethanol, 5 mL of water, and 5 mL of 1M HBr. The solution was heated to ∼70 °C and evaporated to dryness at that temperature. A few red, nearly opaque platelets were able to be separated out from the solid mass. A crystal with dimensions approximately 0.28 × 0.11 × 0.08 mm was selected for the diffraction study.
elements.clean_text: (dBrmqH)CuBr  2   (2). 0.5 mmol of CuBr2 (0.112 g) and 0.5 mmol of dmq (0.079 g) were dissolved in 50 mL of 95% ethanol, 5 mL of water, and 5 mL of 1M HBr. The solution was heated to ~70 °C and evaporated to dryness at that temperature. A few red, nearly opaque platelets were able to be separated out from the solid mass. A crystal with dimensions approximately 0.28 × 0.11 × 0.08 mm was selected for the diffraction study.

elements.content: (dmq)Cu 2 Cl 2 (3). Copper(II) chloride dihydrate (0.748 g, 4.39 mmol) was added to 30 mL of 95% ethanol. The copper salt dissolved to give a green solution. The 2,3-dimethylquinozaline (0.708 g, 4.71 mmol) was dissolved in 30 mL of warm 95% ethanol. The copper solution was then added to the warm, colorless dmq solution to give an emerald green solution. Upon evaporation of the solvent, reddish brown crystals began to form. The crystals were collected by filtration and allowed to air dry. Yield:  0.244 g, 31%. Elemental Analysis:  Calcd. C, 33.72; H, 2.83; N, 7.86; Cl, 19.90; Found C, 34.24; H, 2.90; N, 7.94; Cl, 19.50. IR (KBr):  3019.8 w, 1545.5 w, 1490.1 m, 1396.2 m, 1376.4 m, 1331.4 m, 1195.9 m, 1177.2 m, 1136.6 m, 999.9 m, 958.9 m, 834.5 m, 771.3 s.

elements.content:
Elemental analyses were carried out by Desert Analytical (Phoenix, Arizona). The IR measurements were made on a Perkin−Elmer FT-1000 instrument.

X-ray Diffraction. Data were collected on a Bruker three-circle platform diffractometer equipped with a CCD detector, using the SMART software, at −70 °C for 1 and 22 °C for 2, and Mo K radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data were processed using the SAINT8 software, and absorption corrections were performed using the SADABS9 program. The structures of the bromide compounds were solved by the direct method using the SHELX-90 program and refined by the least-squares method on F 2 using SHELXL-97, incorporated in SHELXTL, version 5.10. The crystals used for the diffraction study showed no appreciable decomposition during data collection. Crystals of the chloride compound were invariably twinned, and it was impossible to obtain a satisfactory structure solution. Table summarizes the most important structural and refinement parameters, while a list of important distances and angles is given in Table . Figures and illustrate the molecular species.

The data were processed using the SAINT8 software,  and absorption corrections were performed using the SADABS9 program. The structures of the bromide compounds were solved by the direct method using the SHELX-90 program and refined by the least-squares method on F 2 using SHELXL-97, incorporated in SHELXTL, version 5.10. The crystals used for the diffraction study showed no appreciable decomposition during data collection. Crystals of the chloride compound were invariably twinned, and it was impossible to obtain a satisfactory structure solution. Table  summarizes the most important structural and refinement parameters, while a list of important distances and angles is given in Table . Figures  and  illustrate the molecular species.

The reaction of the Cu(II) halides with dmq to form compounds 1 and 3 proceeded spontaneously with the slow formation of red−brown crystals over a period of several hours to days, depending on temperature. Their IR spectra were virtually identical, indicating that the interaction of the dmq molecules with the copper halide was very similar in the two compounds. Unfortunately, the inherent twinning of the chloride crystals (compound 3) precluded obtaining a definitive crystal structure. However, it was clearly not isomorphous with the bromide crystals (compound 1). The formation of 2 occurred under more extreme conditions, and limited attempts to obtain pure samples of the material were unsuccessful.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The reaction of the Cu(II) halides with dmq to form compounds 1 and 3 proceeded spontaneously with the slow formation of red-brown crystals over a period of several hours to days, depending on temperature. Their IR spectra were virtually identical, indicating that the interaction of the dmq molecules with the copper halide was very similar in the two compounds. Unfortunately, the inherent twinning of the chloride crystals (compound 3) precluded obtaining a definitive crystal structure. However, it was clearly not isomorphous with the bromide crystals (compound 1). The formation of 2 occurred under more extreme conditions, and limited attempts to obtain pure samples of the material were unsuccessful.

elements.content: The structure observed in 1 is closely related to the crystal chemistry of a series of copper(I) halides that have recently been reported. These studies have elucidated and elaborated upon a number of basic structural types. In the study by Graham et al., a number of basic structural types for copper(I) halide coordination polymers have been elucidated and elaborated upon. One of these is the so-called stairstep polymer (type 1a, Chart ). With nonchelating bidentate ligands, such as pyrazine or quinoxaline, these polymers become linked together into two- dimensional sheets (type 1b). Two notable exceptions to this are the structures of Cu2I2(pyrazine)14a and Cu2I2(4,4‘-bipyridine)5b in which the bidentate ligands bridge Cu2I2 groups to form a chain structure (type 2a, Chart ). The structure of compound 1 is an interesting variant of these structure types. Compound 1 forms a ribbon structure consisting of Cu4Br4 tetramers linked by pairs of dmq ligands, as shown in Figure . These ribbons are readily identified as slices from the parent two-dimensional structure in type 1b. The ribbons are shown schematically in type 2b. Conversely, the structure of 1 can be viewed as a dimer of the chain structure in type 2a.
elements.clean_text: The structure observed in 1 is closely related to the crystal chemistry of a series of copper(I) halides that have recently been reported. These studies have elucidated and elaborated upon a number of basic structural types. In the study by Graham et al., a number of basic structural types for copper(I) halide coordination polymers have been elucidated and elaborated upon. One of these is the so-called stairstep polymer (type 1a, Chart ). With nonchelating bidentate ligands, such as pyrazine or quinoxaline, these polymers become linked together into two- dimensional sheets (type 1b). Two notable exceptions to this are the structures of Cu2I2(pyrazine)14a and Cu2I2(4,4‘-bipyridine)5b in which the bidentate ligands bridge Cu2I2 groups to form a chain structure (type 2a, Chart ). The structure of compound 1 is an interesting variant of these structure types. Compound 1 forms a ribbon structure consisting of Cu4Br4 tetramers linked by pairs of dmq ligands, as shown in Figure . These ribbons are readily identified as slices from the parent two-dimensional structure in type 1b. The ribbons are shown schematically in type 2b. Conversely, the structure of 1 can be viewed as a dimer of the chain structure in type 2a.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="chart" id="ic010280zc00001" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic010280zc00001.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

<fig fig-type="chart" id="ic010280zc00002" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>2</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic010280zc00002.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

In 1, the centrosymmetric Cu4Br4 tetramers are in the stair-step conformation. The ribbons extend in the [001] direction. The inner copper atoms (Cu(1)) are four coordinate, and the outer copper atoms (Cu(2)) are three coordinate. This structure distorts the coordination geometry around Cu(1), with the Cu(1)−Br(2) bond notably elongated to 2.843(1) Å, which is roughly 0.37 Å longer than the other two Cu−Br bonds for that copper atom. The trigonal geometry on Cu(2) also induces a short Cu(1)−Cu(2) interaction of 2.724(1) Å. The presence of two distinct coordination geometries for the copper(I) ions is in contrast to the type 1a and 1b structures, where only tetrahedral geometry is found, and to type 2a, where only trigonal geometry occurs.
elements.clean_text: In 1, the centrosymmetric Cu4Br4 tetramers are in the stair-step conformation. The ribbons extend in the [001] direction. The inner copper atoms (Cu(1)) are four coordinate, and the outer copper atoms (Cu(2)) are three coordinate. This structure distorts the coordination geometry around Cu(1), with the Cu(1)-Br(2) bond notably elongated to 2.843(1) Å, which is roughly 0.37 Å longer than the other two Cu-Br bonds for that copper atom. The trigonal geometry on Cu(2) also induces a short Cu(1)-Cu(2) interaction of 2.724(1) Å. The presence of two distinct coordination geometries for the copper(I) ions is in contrast to the type 1a and 1b structures, where only tetrahedral geometry is found, and to type 2a, where only trigonal geometry occurs.

elements.content: The stepped Cu4X4 core (as contrasted to a cubane-like core) has been found in several other systems, although never incorporated into a chain type structure. Included in this list are the Cu4Br4(φ3P)4 and Cu4I4(φ3P)4 structures, Cu4Br4(φ2PCH2Pφ2)2, and an iodide compound with a bidentate ligand. A variant occurs in [Cu(bpy)2Br]2Cu4Br6, where the Cu4Br4 core is augmented by the coordination of two bromide ions and two bromine atoms from the Cu(II) complex to the four Cu(I) atom core.
elements.clean_text: The stepped Cu4X4 core (as contrasted to a cubane-like core) has been found in several other systems, although never incorporated into a chain type structure. Included in this list are the Cu4Br4(φ3P)4  and Cu4I4(φ3P)4  structures, Cu4Br4(φ2PCH2Pφ2)2, and an iodide compound with a bidentate ligand. A variant occurs in [Cu(bpy)2Br]2Cu4Br6, where the Cu4Br4 core is augmented by the coordination of two bromide ions and two bromine atoms from the Cu(II) complex to the four Cu(I) atom core.

elements.content: Each pair of bridging dmq ligands is related by a center of inversion, so they stack in a parallel fashion, with a strong overlap of the conjugated ring system. The interligand distance is 3.331(6) Å. Because of the bulk of the methyl groups, they extend in opposite sides of the stacked pairs. It is likely the presence of these methyl groups leads to the formation of a ribbon structure rather than a two-dimensional sheet structure. The dmq molecule from the next dimer pair stack such that the methyl groups on one ligand overlap the phenyl group on the adjacent ligand. This led to an interligand distance of 3.515(6) Å.
elements.clean_text: Each pair of bridging dmq ligands is related by a center of inversion, so they stack in a parallel fashion, with a strong overlap of the conjugated ring system. The interligand distance is 3.331(6) Å. Because of the bulk of the methyl groups, they extend in opposite sides of the stacked pairs. It is likely the presence of these methyl groups leads to the formation of a ribbon structure rather than a two-dimensional sheet structure. The dmq molecule from the next dimer pair stack such that the methyl groups on one ligand overlap the phenyl group on the adjacent ligand. This led to an interligand distance of 3.515(6) Å.

elements.content: The structural analysis of 2 revealed that bromination of the methyl groups had occurred during the crystallization of this compound. The organic dmq molecule has been monobrominated on each of the methyl groups to yield 2,3-di(bromomethyl)quinoxaline (henceforth, dBrmq). The solid phase consists of bibridged (CuBr2) n n - chains hydrogen bonded by the monoprotonated (dBrmqH)+ cations. This is illustrated in Figure a. In the solid state, these bromine atoms lie out of the plane of the molecule, with N−C−C−Br torsional angles of 111.9(7) and −72.1(7)° for Br(3) and Br(4), respectively. Each cation forms a N−H···Br hydrogen bond to Br(1), with a N···Br distance of 3.21(1) Å.
elements.clean_text: The structural analysis of 2 revealed that bromination of the methyl groups had occurred during the crystallization of this compound. The organic dmq molecule has been monobrominated on each of the methyl groups to yield 2,3-di(bromomethyl)quinoxaline (henceforth, dBrmq). The solid phase consists of bibridged (CuBr2) n   n  - chains hydrogen bonded by the monoprotonated (dBrmqH)+ cations. This is illustrated in Figure a. In the solid state, these bromine atoms lie out of the plane of the molecule, with N-C-C-Br torsional angles of 111.9(7) and -72.1(7)° for Br(3) and Br(4), respectively. Each cation forms a N-H⋅⋅⋅Br hydrogen bond to Br(1), with a N⋅⋅⋅Br distance of 3.21(1) Å.

elements.content: The Cu(I) ions have a distorted tetrahedral geometry. These tetrahedra are linked together by edge sharing to form chains running parallel to the c axis (Figure b). Crystallographically, the chains have C 2 symmetry. A salient feature is a pronounced dimerization of the chains, with the Cu−Cu distances alternating between 2.814(2) and 3.163(2) Å. This dimerization is induced by the N−H···Br hydrogen bonding documented above. Thus, the Cu−Br(2)−Cu angle (69.65(7)°) is more acute than the Cu−Br(1)−Cu angle (77.14(6)°).
elements.clean_text: The Cu(I) ions have a distorted tetrahedral geometry. These tetrahedra are linked together by edge sharing to form chains running parallel to the c axis (Figure b). Crystallographically, the chains have C 2 symmetry. A salient feature is a pronounced dimerization of the chains, with the Cu-Cu distances alternating between 2.814(2) and 3.163(2) Å. This dimerization is induced by the N-H⋅⋅⋅Br hydrogen bonding documented above. Thus, the Cu-Br(2)-Cu angle (69.65(7)°) is more acute than the Cu-Br(1)-Cu angle (77.14(6)°).

elements.content: Two systems containing (CuBr2) n n - chains similar to those in 2 have been recently reported. These chains are formed for X = Cl-, Br-, and I-, with the paraquat dication. A compound with the 4-methylpyridinium cation has been reported which contains both isolated CuBr4 2- cations and the chain. Thus, it is a type I Robin and Day mixed valence system. This is in contrast to (Me4 - n Et n N)Cu2X4 (X = Cl-, Br-), where type III Robin and Day [Cu(I)Cu(II)X4] n n - chain systems are found. Finally, in (Et2NH2)2(Cu3Br8) (CuBr2), bibridged Cu(II) chains exist with (CuBr2) n stoichiometry.
elements.clean_text: Two systems containing (CuBr2) n   n  - chains similar to those in 2 have been recently reported. These chains are formed for X = Cl-, Br-, and I-, with the paraquat dication. A compound with the 4-methylpyridinium cation has been reported which contains both isolated CuBr4 2- cations and the chain. Thus, it is a type I Robin and Day mixed valence system. This is in contrast to (Me4 -  n Et n N)Cu2X4 (X = Cl-, Br-), where type III Robin and Day [Cu(I)Cu(II)X4] n   n  - chain systems are found. Finally, in (Et2NH2)2(Cu3Br8) (CuBr2), bibridged Cu(II) chains exist with (CuBr2) n  stoichiometry.

elements.content: A number of examples of halogenation of organic species in the presence of copper(II) halides have been observed in structural studies in our laboratory. Most of these have involved halogenation of activated pyridinium cations, such as various 2-aminopyridinium derivatives. Recently, the bromination of the phenyl ring in the 3-chloroanilinium cation was observed. The result reported here is the first example we have observed involving saturated hydrocarbon substitution. This type of reaction, however, is not unknown. Kosower et al. observed chlorination of the hydrocarbon backbone in a bis-dione molecule. The bromination of a methyl group on an acetyl derivative of an activated phenolic system is another example. A plausible mechanism for the reaction involves an analogy to the alkylation of activated enolate complexes. Upon coordination of one of the quinoxaline nitrogen atoms to the Cu(II) ion, the exo C−CH3 bonds attain a greater emamine character, allowing a Br- anion to displace one the hydrogen atoms.
elements.clean_text: A number of examples of halogenation of organic species in the presence of copper(II) halides have been observed in structural studies in our laboratory. Most of these have involved halogenation of activated pyridinium cations, such as various 2-aminopyridinium derivatives. Recently, the bromination  of the phenyl ring in the 3-chloroanilinium cation was observed. The result reported here is the first example we have observed involving saturated hydrocarbon substitution. This type of reaction, however, is not unknown. Kosower et al. observed chlorination of the hydrocarbon backbone in a bis-dione molecule. The bromination of a methyl group on an acetyl derivative of an activated phenolic system is another example. A plausible mechanism for the reaction involves an analogy to the alkylation of activated enolate complexes. Upon coordination of one of the quinoxaline nitrogen atoms to the Cu(II) ion, the exo C-CH3 bonds attain a greater emamine character, allowing a Br- anion to displace one the hydrogen atoms.

cln_elements.content:
Syntheses. (dmq)Cu 2 Br 2 (1). Anhydrous copper(II) bromide (1.03 g, 4.62 mmol) was added to 30 mL of 95% ethanol. The mixture was warmed, and the copper salt dissolved upon the addition of 5 mL of distilled water to give a green/black solution. The 2,3-dimethylquinozaline (0.722 g, 4.56 mmol) was dissolved in 30 mL of warm 95% ethanol. The warm copper solution was then added to the warm, colorless dmq solution to give a reddish brown solution. Upon evaporation of the solvent, reddish brown crystals began to form. The crystals were collected by filtration and allowed to air dry. Yield:  0.577 g, 56%. Elemental Analysis:  Calcd. C, 26.98; H, 2.26; N, 6.29; Br, 35.90; Found C, 26.96; H, 2.19; N, 6.24; Br, 35.92. IR (KBr):  3009.4 w, 1553.1 w, 1487.5 m, 1396.5 m, 1379.1 m, 1332.1 m, 1198.5 m, 1175.9 m, 1136.1 m, 1001.6 m, 957.8 m, 836.3 m, 771.9 s. A crystal with dimensions approximately 0.16 × 0.07 × 0.03 mm was selected for the diffraction study.

(dBrmqH)CuBr 2 (2). 0.5 mmol of CuBr2 (0.112 g) and 0.5 mmol of dmq (0.079 g) were dissolved in 50 mL of 95% ethanol, 5 mL of water, and 5 mL of 1M HBr. The solution was heated to ∼70 °C and evaporated to dryness at that temperature. A few red, nearly opaque platelets were able to be separated out from the solid mass. A crystal with dimensions approximately 0.28 × 0.11 × 0.08 mm was selected for the diffraction study.

(dmq)Cu 2 Cl 2 (3). Copper(II) chloride dihydrate (0.748 g, 4.39 mmol) was added to 30 mL of 95% ethanol. The copper salt dissolved to give a green solution. The 2,3-dimethylquinozaline (0.708 g, 4.71 mmol) was dissolved in 30 mL of warm 95% ethanol. The copper solution was then added to the warm, colorless dmq solution to give an emerald green solution. Upon evaporation of the solvent, reddish brown crystals began to form. The crystals were collected by filtration and allowed to air dry. Yield:  0.244 g, 31%. Elemental Analysis:  Calcd. C, 33.72; H, 2.83; N, 7.86; Cl, 19.90; Found C, 34.24; H, 2.90; N, 7.94; Cl, 19.50. IR (KBr):  3019.8 w, 1545.5 w, 1490.1 m, 1396.2 m, 1376.4 m, 1331.4 m, 1195.9 m, 1177.2 m, 1136.6 m, 999.9 m, 958.9 m, 834.5 m, 771.3 s.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Syntheses. (dmq)Cu  2  Br  2   (1). Anhydrous copper(II) bromide (1.03 g, 4.62 mmol) was added to 30 mL of 95% ethanol. The mixture was warmed, and the copper salt dissolved upon the addition of 5 mL of distilled water to give a green/black solution. The 2,3-dimethylquinozaline (0.722 g, 4.56 mmol) was dissolved in 30 mL of warm 95% ethanol. The warm copper solution was then added to the warm, colorless dmq solution to give a reddish brown solution. Upon evaporation of the solvent, reddish brown crystals began to form. The crystals were collected by filtration and allowed to air dry. Yield: 0.577 g, 56%. Elemental Analysis: Calcd. C, 26.98; H, 2.26; N, 6.29; Br, 35.90; Found C, 26.96; H, 2.19; N, 6.24; Br, 35.92. IR (KBr): 3009.4 w, 1553.1 w, 1487.5 m, 1396.5 m, 1379.1 m, 1332.1 m, 1198.5 m, 1175.9 m, 1136.1 m, 1001.6 m, 957.8 m, 836.3 m, 771.9 s. A crystal with dimensions approximately 0.16 × 0.07 × 0.03 mm was selected for the diffraction study. 

 (dBrmqH)CuBr  2   (2). 0.5 mmol of CuBr2 (0.112 g) and 0.5 mmol of dmq (0.079 g) were dissolved in 50 mL of 95% ethanol, 5 mL of water, and 5 mL of 1M HBr. The solution was heated to ~70 °C and evaporated to dryness at that temperature. A few red, nearly opaque platelets were able to be separated out from the solid mass. A crystal with dimensions approximately 0.28 × 0.11 × 0.08 mm was selected for the diffraction study. 

 (dmq)Cu  2  Cl  2   (3). Copper(II) chloride dihydrate (0.748 g, 4.39 mmol) was added to 30 mL of 95% ethanol. The copper salt dissolved to give a green solution. The 2,3-dimethylquinozaline (0.708 g, 4.71 mmol) was dissolved in 30 mL of warm 95% ethanol. The copper solution was then added to the warm, colorless dmq solution to give an emerald green solution. Upon evaporation of the solvent, reddish brown crystals began to form. The crystals were collected by filtration and allowed to air dry. Yield: 0.244 g, 31%. Elemental Analysis: Calcd. C, 33.72; H, 2.83; N, 7.86; Cl, 19.90; Found C, 34.24; H, 2.90; N, 7.94; Cl, 19.50. IR (KBr): 3019.8 w, 1545.5 w, 1490.1 m, 1396.2 m, 1376.4 m, 1331.4 m, 1195.9 m, 1177.2 m, 1136.6 m, 999.9 m, 958.9 m, 834.5 m, 771.3 s.

metadata.title:
Novel Copper(I) Halide Polymers:  Structures of
Cu2Br2(2,3-dimethylquinoxaline) and
(2,3-Di(bromomethyl)quinoxalinium)CuBr2. The
Continuing Saga of Copper(II) Bromide
Reactivity with Organoamines
